US doesn't have that so there's no point having this conversation until the election year.

Comment: which is unfortunately the result of her campaign manager and campaign issues. Much of the "its okay guys, we are here for the status quo" was a result of megadonors telling her to reign in her "leftism" or they were going to pull funding. On top of that, more populist messaging was simply not allowed on news media platforms, not without exorbitant extra costs.  Granted, these are the excuses her campaign manager gave, when he focused his efforts on getting conservatives to switch sides, instead of whipping up the party base. Anyone who actually knew voters, could have told you emotion over reason was the name of the game. That being said, Conservatism really is the primary issue, as a whole.  Conservatives on both sides of the aisle control the purse strings, and unfortunately few of them seriously thought Trump was going to make due on his promises that he was going to rule like a dictator. Most of those that did know, supported Trump in the name of either increasing their own personal power, or WANTED the stripping of legal rights.  Democrat leadership wants the same thing all old people want: a peaceful and slow end, because they can't handle change. Progressives scared them, because even though objectively what progressives want is for the better of the nation, it still means uncertainty that old Republicans and Democrats do not want.  But by that same token, by getting Trump elected, change of a different sort has come. A change for the worse for almost everyone. A change they can handle even less than they could proposed progressive changes.  Assuming the planet survives this, Boomers will have to be demonized for the rest of history, because the past 50 years of political and economic turmoil can pretty much be laid at their feet. The world ticks ever closer to nuclear midnight, for what amounts to petty generational pride.
